passage_text: The US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) estimates that the social cost of carbon is around $39 per ton, and you can argue the number higher or lower. For now, though, a price starting around $30 per ton would put Oregon or Washington in line with other programs and close to the economist-approved price.

Looking into the future, the not-for-profit Investor Responsibility Research Center prices carbon at $28.24 per ton in the year 2012, and as such they say annual carbon costs would total $92.8 billion.

With an average price of $20 per ton of carbon dioxide–which is consistent with European Union prices over the past two years–the S&P 500 companies, should they start paying full value for their carbon emissions, will have to write a collective check for $60 billion to $80 billion each year.
